<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<RelativeLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto"
    xmlns:tools="http://schemas.android.com/tools"
    android:id="@+id/activity_user_information"
    android:layout_width="match_parent"
    android:layout_height="match_parent"
    tools:context="com.technas.noqueue.activity.ServiceInputActivity">

    <android.support.design.widget.CoordinatorLayout
        android:id="@+id/main_content"
        android:layout_width="match_parent"
        android:layout_height="match_parent">

        <android.support.design.widget.AppBarLayout
            android:id="@+id/appbar"
            android:layout_width="match_parent"
            android:layout_height="wrap_content"
            android:theme="@style/ThemeOverlay.AppCompat.Dark.ActionBar">

            <android.support.v7.widget.Toolbar
                android:id="@+id/toolbar"
                android:layout_width="match_parent"
                android:layout_height="?attr/actionBarSize"
                android:background="?attr/colorPrimary"
                app:layout_scrollFlags="scroll|enterAlways"
                app:popupTheme="@style/ThemeOverlay.AppCompat.Light" />

            <android.support.design.widget.TabLayout
                android:id="@+id/tabs"
                android:layout_width="match_parent"
                android:layout_height="wrap_content" />
        </android.support.design.widget.AppBarLayout>

        <android.support.v4.view.ViewPager
            android:id="@+id/viewpager"
            android:layout_margin="@dimen/activity_vertical_margin"
            android:layout_width="match_parent"
            android:layout_height="match_parent"
            app:layout_behavior="@string/appbar_scrolling_view_behavior" />

    </android.support.design.widget.CoordinatorLayout>

</RelativeLayout>

text: Working with Realm currently requires a lot of fiddling and why?
Realm could be so much better if only we had converters

<@U061HDV96> it's a shame that it adds pretty much double the complexity to Realm's API due to having to support arbitrary types in RealmQueries that aren't necessarily RealmObjects, and check against possible converters and all that; so it is no wonder they never added it beyond `Idea Backlog`.
I'd rather have blackberry support back so that I can upgrade, lol
I disagree
I think this is an essential feature
And having 30 or so atrocities doesn't make up for it
we clearly have a different definition for the term "essential".
I'm writing a reply btw.
i edited my reply about 3 times
i hope Github manages that, lol
<@U39P7U6EP> alright, I replied to all of them now.
I just feel that is a huge pain to maintain my Realm classes.
<@U39P7U6EP> the more I read the replies, the more I feel like Realm isn't something that should be used for larger projects but more for smaller projects.
The more I use realm, the more I think I should be using something else in this project

Any help would be very appreciated :slightly_smiling_face:
Have you got an extra “/” in there somewhere or something like that?
See if you can debug and find the uri you’re actually sending to in app

But searching around I cant find how to specify get but still send request parameters
Query params?
Yeah sorry
<@U3G2SQVPA> that’s because you should not send a body with a GET method (liar, the backend should ignore the body)
but you can add <@U1ST4SMTR> to add it to URL
or use @Path to modify it
oops, sorry <@U1ST4SMTR> :joy:

<https://dev.tescolabs.com/locations/search?sort=near:LN2>
So the Url I was using was <https://dev.tescolabs.com/locations/search> and then adding a request body to it with the sort parameter
That is a query parameter

the reason I was trying to do it that way is because I want to change the query parameter based on user input
How would I need to proceed in that case?

Hi ! In the MVP pattern, when are the presenters garbage collected ?
I never liked NoSql
I tried but I just don't like it
I always hated mongoDb
<@U200KUU56> when views are
Presenter are GC'd when their ref count = 0 same as any object
Java doesn’t use ref count
okay, so if I subscribe to an observable I must dispose of it in the detachView
GC root
then
When the GC root doesnt exist
I forgot :slightly_smiling_face:
<@U200KUU56> Yes, typically people use composite subscription and drop on the lifecycle end
but it is not about GC, it’s about lifecycle
yeah I don't know why I thought it would be different that in the activity
I'm using SuscribeWith + dispose, but I suppose unsubscribe work the same way
I unsubscribe in the destroy method
Call that when your presenter will be destroyed
I should have said when the GC root is no longer reachable
yeah in the destroy method, I call the detachView method of the presenter
so I should call dispose here
<@U3E2EEX38> you are mixing onDestroy with GC
no
I'm not
I am saying that is where I kill the subs
Nothing to do with GC
and onDestroy in my presenter is actually not the Android lifecycle onDestroy since I have a single activity with multiple views
But the original question was when is the Presenter GC'd? It is Gc'd the same as any other object
To determine which objects are no longer in use, the JVM intermittently runs what is very aptly called a mark-and-sweep algorithm
copy pasta
Anyone here tried SnappyDB?

Also I was wondering, is there some kind of simple guide which references the use case for `AndroidSchedulers.mainThread` , `<http://Schedulers.io|Schedulers.io>` , `Schedulers.newThread` and others
In order to know which to use in RxAndroid
`<http://Schedulers.io|Schedulers.io>` is for network requests
mainthread is the main thread
they are self explanatory imo
yeah but what benefit is there for mainthread for example
Some things must be run on the main Thread for the UI, this is more of a general Android question
its not specific to RxJava
oh I see, thanks
The UI thread and the main thread are the same in Android
ok, so if I'm gonna change some UI (ex: toggling a checkbox), I must use AndroidSchedulers.mainThread ?
even if the observer is in the presenter
Ye
`observeOn(mainThread)`
